newsitem.title: USA: CSCE coffee ends weaker, but support holds.
newsitem.headline: CSCE coffee ends weaker, but support holds.

text.p: CSCE coffee futures ended slightly lower Wednesday, pressured by light fund liquidation and commission house selling, traders said.
But trade buying emerged at the lows, limiting losses and keeping the benchmark December contract well above key support at 110.00 cents a lb, dealers said.

December coffee ended down 0.50 cent a lb, to 112.80 cents, after ranging between 114.00 and 111.30. Spot September ended 0.85 cent lower, at 124.20, while the remaining months finished 0.70 to 0.75 weaker.

The market took a downturn at the open on follow-through fund liquidation, traders said. Fund liquidation on Tuesday drove prices down sharply after the CFTC Commitment of Traders report released Friday showed a sharp increase in non-commercial long positions.
"The funds are still long," one trader said. "They liquidated some, but from what I see they still have a way to go."
Technically, traders said after 110.00 cents, December's next level of support would be near 106.00-105.00 cents. Resistance was seen at 114.50 cents, followed by 116.00 cents.
The CSCE reported after Tuesday's close that U.S. certified coffee stocks in the week ended August 30 rose 2,250 60-kg bags, to 41,563 60-kg bags.

But while September's open interest continued to decline, it remained relatively high Tuesday at 1,116 lots, or the equivalent of about 317,045 60-kg bags of coffee. Since September entered notice period August 22, a total of six delivery notices have been issued.
